bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to P.M. Hamer, March 19, 1942

div1.p: Hench thanks Hamer and the National Archives staff for their help and inquires about two missing volumes of records. He also requests records on Godfrey.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to P.M. Hamer, March 19, 1942
div1.opener:
Copy to Mr. Jerome Thomases
National Archives Building
March 19, 1942
Mr. P. M. Hamer, Archivist
National Archives
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Hamer:
div1.p:
I have recently received the rather extensive order of photostated
and microfilmed items which I selected in January, 1942. I am delighted to
have these. The National Archives is doing a splendid service and I want
to express my sincere appreciation for the many courtesies extended to me
by all of your staff, particularly Mr. Thomases, Mr. Sippolyte, Mr. Critchfield
and Miss Cobb.

Mr. Thomases showed me Volume 11, Register of Medical Officers, in
the office of the Surgeon General, Records of the War Department. I had
photostated pages 149, 150, 151 and 88, giving the whereabouts of Major
Walter Reed from apparently 1898 to his death in 1901. At the time I was
there, Mr. Thomases could not locate the previous volume and the volume
containing his earlier army record. Mr. Critchfield showed me the personal
file on Walter Reed in the old Record Division of the Adjutant General's
office, but this record of Reed is not nearly so complete as that in the
Register of Medical Officers. I would appreciate it greatly if you would
inform me whether Mr. Thomases or another of your colleagues could locate
the previous volume with the other data concerning Walter Reed. If so,
I should like to have photostats of each page.

The same applies to the personal record of First Lieutenant, later
Captain Guy M. Godfrey, Assistant Surgeon. In the heretofore mentioned Volume 11,
on pages 460, 462 and 533 I found records of Dr. Godfrey from January 31, 1898
to December 31, 1902, but I am anxious to obtain the same detailed record of
his career between the time of his enlistment and January, 1898, and subsequent
to 1902 at the time of his death.
Any help that you can give me would be greatly appreciated.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P.S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
